newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: SWISS CABINET PLANS CUTS IN 1998 BUDGET DEFICIT.
newsitem.headline: SWISS CABINET PLANS CUTS IN 1998 BUDGET DEFICIT.

text.p: The Swiss cabinet has drafted a plan to lower the federal government's 1998 deficit to roughly 5.5 billion Swiss francs ($3.6 billion) from 8.7 billion francs projected earlier, a Federal Finance Ministry spokesman said on Thursday.
"Savings will be taken in all areas," he said.
The cuts are part of a longer-term plan to reduce the deficit to four billion francs by 1999 and to no higher than one billion francs by 2001.
By Wednesday evening, the cabinet nearly completed the plan, expected to be finalised later this month. The plan must be trimmed by another 100 million francs.
"We still haven't reached the goal of 5.5 billion. We have to find around 100 million yet," the spokesman said.
The 1998 deficit would then come close to the projected 1997 shortfall of 5.77 billion francs.
Deficit figures for 1998 exclude a one-time 1.8 billion franc outlay for the Swiss Federal Railway.
To cut costs in 1999 and beyond, the cabinet foresees lowering transportation, social welfare and defense spending.

Swiss economy minister Jean-Pascal Delamuraz, recovering from an operation, was not at Wednesday's meeting. Some of the proposed cuts would fall in his area, including those relating to unemployment compensation, Swiss press said.

With respect to revenues, Swiss news agency SDA reported Swiss Finance Minister Kaspar Villiger said no tax increases are planned beyond those already announced. These include a planned early increase in value-added tax by one percent in 1999, bringing the regular VAT rate up to 7.5 percent.
But Villiger also said he would not be opposed to having experts study if a capital gains tax should be considered if measures are needed to make up for other shortfalls.
